questions.question: What is the correct HTML tag for creating a hyperlink?
questions.explanation: The <a> tag (anchor tag) is used to create hyperlinks in HTML. It requires an href attribute to specify the destination.

questions.question: If you're in a file called index.html and want to link to contact.html in the same directory, what is the simplest path you should use?
questions.explanation: When linking to a file in the same directory, the simplest path is just the filename: contact.html. While './contact.html' is also technically correct (the './' explicitly means 'current directory'), it's redundant and 'contact.html' is the more common and simpler approach.

questions.question: What does the '../' notation mean in a relative path?
questions.explanation: The '../' notation means 'go up one directory level' (parent directory). For example, if you're in home/index.html and want to access test.html in the parent directory, you'd use ../test.html.

questions.question:
Given this directory structure:
```
my_website
├── home
│   └── index.html
└── files
    └── gallery.html
```

If you're editing index.html and want to link to gallery.html, what path should you use?
questions.explanation: You need to go up one directory (../) to reach the parent directory (my_website), then go into the files directory, so the path is ../files/gallery.html.

questions.question: What is an absolute path?
options: A path relative to the current file
A fully qualified URL including protocol, server name, and file path
A path that only includes the filename
questions.explanation: An absolute path is a fully qualified URL that includes the protocol (https://), the server name (example.com), and the file path. It's used when linking to resources on other computers/servers.

questions.question: How do you create an internal link (anchor link) that jumps to a specific section on the same page?
options: Use href='#section-id' with a hash tag followed by the id
questions.explanation: Internal links use a hash tag (#) followed by the id of the target element. For example, Link will jump to an element with id="section1".

questions.question: Which attribute is required for the <a> tag to create a functional link?
questions.explanation: The href attribute is required for the <a> tag. It specifies the destination URL or path of the link.

questions.question:
Given this directory structure:
```
my_website
└── home
    ├── index.html
    └── styles
        └── my_style.css
```

If you're editing index.html and want to link to my_style.css, what path should you use?
questions.explanation: Since styles is a subdirectory within the same directory as index.html, you simply use styles/my_style.css to go into the styles directory and access the file.

questions.question:
Given this directory structure:
```
my_website
├── home
│   ├── index.html
│   └── about.html
├── images
│   └── logo.png
└── files
    └── document.pdf
```

If you're editing index.html and want to link to logo.png, what path should you use?
questions.explanation: You need to go up one directory (../) from home to reach my_website, then go into the images directory, so the path is ../images/logo.png.

questions.question:
Given this directory structure:
```
my_website
├── home
│   └── index.html
└── styles
    └── dark
        └── theme.css
```

If you're editing index.html and want to link to theme.css, what path should you use?
questions.explanation: You need to go up one directory (../) from home to reach my_website, then go into styles, then into dark, so the path is ../styles/dark/theme.css.
